ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Bryan Yoon
Kris Covey
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Byungman Yook
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Byungman Yoon
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Dan Maynard
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Available, helpful, supportive
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Dan Maynard was excellent! Very accessible, always helpful& just a really great TA.
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Dan Maynard
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Dan is a talented scientist and accessible and friendly TA, always willing to work through ideas.
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Daniel Maynard

Instructor: Kristofer Ron Covey  His knowledge in forestry and dedication to share this knowledge with students, characterized Covey. His enthusiasm and skills to manage groups as well as being responsive to students questions any time it raised, contributed significantly to my learning process in this course.
Instructor: Kristofer Ron Covey  Kris Covey

Instructor: Kristofer Ron Covey  Kris was always helpful and nice when we were able to get a hold of him, but he was not often available: we sent him many emails which went unanswered, and it was difficult to get responses from him in a timely fashion. It would have been helpful if he were present more often during our classes and lab sections. The fact that he was not accessible meant that we relied more strongly on the other two TA's, which just made more work for them and was stressful for us.
Instructor: Kristofer Ron Covey  .

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 10 : There was a significant breakdown in pedagogy midway through the course. The lecture material was less focused and hard to review at times.

Question 14The course provided students with academic and professional management assets in broad range of situations and in different types of ecosystems and landscapes. From the skills and knowledge gained in this course, students are able to make any successful and relevant decision in ecosystems management, based on rational evidence. Most importantly, the course skilled students on how science could be valuable in management decision process even in very complex situations across different regions and biota.
There were three professors, and three TAs. Instead of making the course better, it seemed like professors were not very well organized on the lectures and activities.
The course was excellent. In addition the instructor provided some online vignettes which were extremely helpful
Question 3This was a great class, but it had some kinks to work through. The lab component was massive and made the class a lot more week than it needed to be.

This class functioned under a new structure compared to other years, which made it a learning process for faculty, TAs and students. There were some difficulties with time management, especially for assignments and exams, that made the class overwhelming at times. However, it was an excellent class for learning key concepts of ecosystem processes and ecosystem services.

13: This was overall a great class. The field trips were great, and EXTREMELY helpful: it was great to be able to actually get a sense of what we were doing in class and in the lab by going out and seeing it in the field. The lectures were really good and the online vignettes were really helpful and definitely let me learn a lot. I would have loved to have one more field trip.More supervised time in the lab would have been really helpful. If our lab work could fit into the scheduled 9am-12pm lab time on Fridays, that would be ideal. Because we had to have regular lectures, scheduled lab time, AND work in the lab outside of those hours, the work load was a bit too heavy. But overall this was a great class and I learned a lot!

A terrific course. Not only did I learn the basics of ecology, but I was challenged to think beyond the traditional definition of the field. I really enjoyed having the three professors teach the course.

I enjoyed the paper readings and discussions. I thought there was a good mixture of science and management papers. Perhaps one thing to try would be to pair a 'management' paper and also a scientific paper - how does the 'management' paper use the scientific paper? Does it accurately represent the conclusions presented, or is something changed? Etc.The Richardson project was a great component, in that we got to experience fieldwork, labwork, and report writing (as well as seeing how scientists managers have to make some significant interpolations of data).The Gecko Woods project took far too long for how much we learned from it and for its percentage of our entire grade. Even with grouping into three, I'm pretty sure that amount of time that I spent individually on that project was considerably more than any of the three midterms. I would advise rewriting the assignment so that all the computerwork (running the model and making spreadsheets) can be done within the lab period (or within two lab periods) and then the write-up is done outside of lab.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Material and the strength of the intstructor's knowledge
Among the best aspects on the course was the exercise on making a management plan of the Richardson Forest, from data we collected and analyzed along the semester.
Online vignettes, discussion sessions, field trips.

The lab work was certainly the highlight of the course. Being able to see and extrapolate concepts learned in class in the field, cements the content learned and makes the student develop an even higher appreciation for the science.
Labs and field trips.
readings followed by the forum and the class discussion.
I appreciated the reading responses and the facilitated discussions in class.
Dynamic teaching, subject matter
The field trips and lab assignments
The field trips and lab component.
The field trips and the opportunity of building a carbon budget from zero. Also learning about top down controls!
The field trips, lectures, vignettes, and lab work. All were great.

The group work provided a valuable space for exchange; I learned a lot from how my classmates were interpreting the material.Field trips were crucial for contextualizing the material, and for understanding its wider relevance.

The online vignettes were really great, as were the lab components. I liked having the final project based on lab work from the beginning of the semester to bring it all together. The professors were great at trading off the lectures and linking the topics we were discussing to relevant topics that we would be thinking about in our own work. There were a few lectures that talked about large-scale issues that I really loved and made me consider some of my perspectives on environmental issues.

The best aspect of the course was how the students were constantly to challenge to question the current ideas in the fields. We were not simply feed information, but really forced to think and develop our own opinions. I also liked the emphasis on how humans fit within ecosystems and what we can do to ensure change.
Field component; paper discussions.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Coordination between instructors
Our work at the lab would have been improved and done differently. I would suggest that students are supported during their works at laboratories.
The syllabus and assignments were not clear. Instructors appeared to be unorganized.

The second half of the course focused on demonstrating how the cycles and science learned in the first part are influenced by human management systems and how anthropogenic stresses influence these cycles. This was important part in helping us see the relationship between ecology and management. The discussions were provocative but sometimes cyclical and did not provide direction on how to approach combating ecological problems. Though this is not a management course and I recognize there is no simple or straight forward response to addressing ecological disasters, more direction could have been given on tools that have been used to address these problems since a lot of time was focused on management implications for ecosystems and landscapes.
Class needs to be better organized to gain efficiency and maximum learning potential.
More quantitative examples in class
I think the professors were very responsive over the course of the semester to our feedback and improved most of what I would have otherwise suggested.
A reorganization of the field trips relative to the rest of the course might be useful for students to make the most of the trips and their outcome
The exams were unstructured and confusing. They did not reflect materials learned in class.

It would have been useful to have more faculty/TA support for creating the carbon budget, since the student groups were left pretty much on their own. The problem with student groups is that tasks are divided among members, which means that not all students are part of quantifying the budget. This should be reinforced by providing in class exercises in which all students participate.
I didn't get much out of the Geckowoods exercise, so if that could be removed or modified that would be really good.

A bit more clarity about how much time is expected would be useful. There were times that we had assignments that weren't on the syllabus or were more time-consuming than we had expected. But the professors were responsive when this was brought up and they said this would be considered in future versions of this course.
More time in the field would have been helpful with the final project.

Organization? I felt that often the requirements for assignments were unclear - were paper summaries due at 5pm or 9am? Did assignments need to be emailed or uploaded to classesv2?While I didn't think that the first midterm was too difficult, I think we were all a bit surprised at the quantitative aspect of it, especially since we had done very little of that previously (except for one in-class exercise with nitrogen, and the sample exam problem - which created lots more questions!) Arguing over the interpretation of the questions regarding the numbers was what made the test so lengthy, not necessarily a lack of understanding of (or failure to study) the material. So make sure that the exam material matches class material not only in topic but also in type.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes but could be strengthened.

The relationship between lectures and discussions was effective. Even when lab guidelines are available, a peer support for the lab works still needed in some circumstances, should some students need support as coming from different background disciplines.
The lab was an integral part of the course and the TAs were excellent in helping us process lab samples and discussing ensuring we understood the lab and the relevance of the concepts.
There was large disconnect between what professors taught and their expectations and the TAs running the lab component which increased confusion in the course.
very effective, excellent work
The lab work was valuable and the content contributed well to the rest of the class.
Yes, practice sessions for the simulation labs would have improved our understanding of the tool and its underlying concepts.
Yes, class and lab were well integrated.
The relationship was effective but, the workload was too intense.

It was fairly good, but communication between teachers and TAs could have been improved: often the TAs didn't know what was going on in lecture and the professors weren't always clear about what was to be done in lab section.
The relationship was really great and served to reinforce a lot of what we were doing in class. There were a few that could be improved in execution but the concepts of the labs were great.

Yes! The carbon budget project related and contextualize the lectures and helped me put what I learned into practice. This was the first time Ive worked on a project like that and what i learned from that is enormous.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: TAs need to attend lecture.
Dan was great. It would have been nice to have him on hand more often, especially during labs, but I felt like he was totally accessible when we needed him, especially for the final project.
Dan was a great TA! He was always there when we had questions. No improvement needed!!
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Bryan was excellent.
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Strengths: responsible, knowledgeable.
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Available, Knowledgeable, resourceful.
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Dan was very helpful, always available and helped our group think through how we were going to present parts of our final project.
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  TA was available and very helpful. I could not come up with a weakness
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Dan was knowledgeable, accessible, kind, and always willing to meet and provide support and work through concepts/ideas. Fantastic TA!

Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Daniel was excellent. He was really available for questions, was really useful in completing the lab work and was proactive in identifying potential issues in our lab work (which was especially useful since many of us did not have much lab experience).

Instructor: Kristofer Ron Covey  Covey's strengthens include strong knowledge and skills in forestry, very good communicator and concise in his answers. His weakness was that he wrote back rarely when we sent an email to address a quick question regarding our lab project.
Instructor: Kristofer Ron Covey  Kris was a knowledgeable TF. The problem was that he wasn't available very much and did not answer emails promptly.
Instructor: Kristofer Ron Covey  The teaching assistant for our group was not as responsive as would have been desired.
Instructor: Kristofer Ron Covey  Kris was a great teacher, but if he could improve his responsiveness and accessibility, he would be even better.
Instructor: Kristofer Ron Covey  While Kris was great at explaining forests concepts, accessibility was sometimes an issue.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Part of a developing a systems' perspective and important in filling in a knowledge gap concerning ecology.

Coming from a professional background in biodiversity conservation and sustainable development, where dynamics with ecosystem uncertainties along with conservation policies and local community desiderata render the whole conservation and management of the environment a complex puzzle, the course fits very well in my professional programs and academic expectations
Understanding how actions taken on one landscape can affect others is a concept I know will be important in helping me critically analyze systems in other courses I take and within my career.
Great foundation course!
This course fits very well with my overall program as it addresses almost all aspects of environmental issues

Of the classes that I took this semester, this one was the hardest fit into my overall program. The content in the class was great and I was able to indirectly apply it to my own work, but there was never an opportunity to directly relate it backto my field of study. It would be nice to find a way to do at least one personally-driven project.
Provided a systems perspective of ecological concepts - an important tool for environmental managers and educators like myself
It fits perfectly because my interest is in understanding basic concepts that have an influence over ecosystem conservation.
This was a great primer on environmental science for someone like me who has only a light science background.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: MEM prerequisite
To fill the gaps I encountered in my professional experience as protected area managers and and conservation policy maker
I took this course since it was a highly recommended foundations course and I wanted to have a firmer understanding of the science behind environmental management.
Gain greater understanding of systems perspective.
To have a strong foundation and first understanding of environmental issues.
For an overview of ecological concepts
I particularly enjoyed learning about top-down controls and the role of wildlife and biodiversity in regulating ecosystem services. This a topic that I would like to pursue further.
To gain environmental science concepts because I had a social science and not natural science background.
Wanted a background in ecosystems for my future career.
Useful knowledge to have.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes but could have learned more. Also, some of the assigned coursework needs review.
Yes, they did.
No. The material to assimilate was not well organized.
The knowledge and skills I gained from the course met and exceeded my expectations.
yes, very much so.
The skills and knowledge met my expectations and gave me a strong prerequisite for other classes. I more comfortable with many concepts.
Yes
Yes.
Definitely.
They exceeded my expectations. I highly recommend this course.
yes. I have a solid foundation in the subject now.
YES

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Good team building, potential for conflict

The discussion groups were very important in a way that students shared different conservation and management experiences, assumptions and suggestions. I didn't find any disadvantage for the discussion groups.
It is hard to find times to work together, and it is hard to punish free-riders.
The group project was important in simulating how we would analyze and develop a management plan for an ecosystem with partners.
great way to collaborate and to use all our skill sets to work towards common goal
Working in group was more than beneficial in the sens of sharing ideas, several discussions to provide the best solutions to a problem

The group work was good because it's great exposure to working as a team and leveraging other people's strengths and weaknesses. I really valued a lot of the people that I got to work with and learned a lot from them. It would have been nice to have the final group project due during the last week of class with the presentation, rather than after the fact. Commitments built up and it became very difficult to commit as a group to work on it. I think we would have had a stronger product if we had simply submitted it with the presentation.
It was great to work within a team and bounce ideas and concepts about the work at hand off my colleagues.
I learned a lot working in a group. We were able to accomplish more than if we worked individually.

The advantage was having a learning team to share experiences and knowledge with. The disadvantage is that task are dividing between the group members, and some of the learning processes are lost because of this.

Although I feltthat working in a group meant that every project I was part of took much longer than it needed to, I also learned a huge amount from my classmates that I would not have if we only worked alone. It was a crucial and huge part of my experience in the class
I really enjoyed the group work and it was fun working with classmates and having people to discuss ideas with.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would strongly encourage them to take the course, not just MEM!
I highly recommend
Intense but worthwhile
Its a great class, but it takes a lot of time and effort, so be sure to think about this when designing other courses workload.

I highly recommend this course if you don't have a strong science background, but be prepared that it will take up a lot of time during the semester. However, it did not require a formal final, after the last class beyond an assignment related to a presentation that we already completed. So while it took up a lot of time during the semester, it was nice to have less to do for this class during finals week.
Do the readings, don't
